page.title: 19Wildlife in the area.
page.content: Woozeley Brook meanders through the parishes of Newbold Pacey and Ashorne. Mostly it is about 2 metres wide and a half metre deep with a muddy bed. It is flanked by high hedges of hawthorn, willow, crab apple, hazel, blackberry and elderberry. The life in the stream consists of sticklebacks, minnows, bullheads, water snails and beetles. Watervoles can be seen swimming dodging the nests of morehens. In the summer dragonflies dart about.The occasional grass snake slithers along the grassy banks. Many birds can be seen. Pigeons, crows, and rooks being the most common.Thrushes and robins are declining but we still see lots of blue tits,great tits and members of the finch family. Lapwings have nested this season after many years of being threatened by chemicals from farming.
